WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN FAMILIES EAT?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name MRS. FRED. JOHNSTON
Address S.W.O.W.D.E.N.
Birthplace ONTARIO

1. DIRECTORY USES

What year did you start housekeeping in western Canada? 1910
Where did you set up housekeeping? MOOSAMIN, SASK.
Where had you been living before that? MARKDALE, ONTARIO
For how many people did you prepare meals? FOUR
How far was it to your nearest store? 4 MILES
How often could a visit be made to the store? ONCE A WEEK
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Sugar, tea, Baking Powder, Baking Soda, Flour, Yeast cake, oatmeal, beans, molasses, corn meal.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? FIVE ROSES or QUAKER
In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lbs. Sack
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $3.00
How much did you use graham flour? None
Whole wheat flour? Very little—own grown
Was flour milled locally? No How far away? _______ What year? _______
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 85 cents
What other grain products did you use? None except oatmeal
Cornmeal? 20 lbs Whole wheat? Some Farine? _______
Other? ____________________________________________________________
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes
How did you grind it? In own grain grinder.
1910. Johnston, Mrs. Fred.

   In what quantities did you buy?

3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? Usually by 10 lb. sack.
What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? 80 cents.
What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Edward's Syrup.
What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 4 lb. tin.
At what price? Usually about $6.00.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? From own cows.
Butter? Our own product. Eggs? Own hens' eggs.
What was the price of butter? 25 cents.
Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes. How? By water glass or salt.
Did you make butter? Yes. Cheese? Yes.
What kind of cheese? Home made at home by a press.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Our own hogs.
How did you get fresh meat? From the Butcher Shop, which was very seldom.
How often did you get fresh meat?
How did you preserve meat? Salt and sugar and smoking the meat.
Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? No.
If so what year was it organized?
Did you use game? In winter. What kinds? Jumper deer.
For how long?
What part did fish play in the family diet? We usually went to Montana for 100 lbs. fresh fish for winter use.
Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh.
Kinds? White fish and mullet.
3. SUGAR AND SPICES

In what quantity did you buy sugar? Usually 1 lb. 10 oz.

Was there any other sugar bought? Yes, 2 lbs.

Was there any other spice bought? Yes, 1 lb.

4. BUTTER

How much butter did you buy? Usually 1 lb.

Did you buy any other butter? Yes, 2 lbs.

5. MEAT

What kind of meat did you buy? Usually beef.

Did you buy any other meat? Yes, pork.

6. VEGETABLES

What kind of vegetables did you buy? Usually carrots.

Did you buy any other vegetables? Yes, potatoes.

7. FRUITS

What kind of fruits did you buy? Usually apples.

Did you buy any other fruits? Yes, bananas.

8. OTHER

What other items did you buy? Usually bread.

Did you buy any other items? Yes, milk.
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? Blue Ribbon At what price? 60 cents.

What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Ground.

Price? 50 cents What other beverages were used? Milk for the children.

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping? 5¢ a bag.

Could you get potatoes at the store? Yes.

If not, where from? Own garden.

What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of: Potatoes 1911 Cabbage 1911 Carrots 1911 Onions 1911 Turnips 1911 Beets 1911.

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? 25 lbs.

How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? Bulk.

What weight? 25 lbs How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? Both bulk and boxes.

What was the price of prunes? 20¢ a lb.

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)?

Raisins and currants.

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? No.

Peas? Corned corn? Corned beans? Corned Saskatoons?

Other foods? Own products.

What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 1911.

What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? 1911 and ever since.

What year did you first preserve meat by canning? 1911.

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Canning.

To what extent? Usually bought but made very limited quantity.

Did you make your own vinegar?

10. Baking

What type of yeast did you use? Royal yeast cake.

Did you make yeast for your own use? No. Using starter? Sometimes.

Using hops? Salt rising?

Did you buy baking powder? Yes. Baking soda? Yes.

The above list is for the house.
13. Laundry
Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? Bought some & made my own.
If you made your own, did you use lye? Yes, wood ashes?
What kind of laundry soap did the grocer sell? Sunlight, Comfort, Fels Naptha, and others.

14. Fuel
What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Wood usually poplar.
Where did you get your fuel? From our own homestead.

Nations any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.
The last few years the farmers are beginning to use Coal and a few have oil burners.

15. Methods of Cooking and Types of Utensils
For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) No.
Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) No.

By whom was your first cook stove made? The family.
What year was it purchased? 1910 Price? $10.00
What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) Tin and graniteware.

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) Earthenware.

When did you first see enamel ware? Before 1910.
Aluminum? About 1910.

16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Describe any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

I do not remember. The butcher using wax paper to wrap the meat in 1910 or for some years later.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

1910. Breakfast: Coffee, oatmeal porridge, toast & eggs.
Dinner: Tea, potatoes, vegetables, meat & dessert.
Supper: Tea, bread & butter, potatoes & meat or eggs or fish, fruit of some kind—perhaps biscuits or cake.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

Fred Johnston, May Johnston, Carl & Verna (children)
Guests: Ed Thompson, Lena Thompson & children—Eileen, Alvin & Bill—Ralph Johnston & Ken Johnston.

Menu—Roast Goose, plum pudding, bread, potatoes, vegetables, butter, sugar tea, valo, mince cake.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

No—we lived on a farm which always gave us a good wholesome living as we always had our own cows, hens and hogs. So we had our own eggs, butter and meat also our own potatoes and vegetables.
I do not remember the butcher using our way after the war in 1918 or for years later.

17. Give a typical day's menu. (Observe time & amount for the children.)

18. How did you serve your first Christmas dinner in wartime? 2nd?

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level? Having no food or too little?

20. Use lived on a farm which always gave us a good wholesome living as we always had our own cows, hens and hogs. So we had our own eggs, butter and meat also our own potatoes and vegetables.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

To my way of living I do not see much change except now we have the waterless cookers and the pressure cookers to use.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

I always can my own fruits and vegetables also chicken, meat and fish also make my own butter and I buy very little canned goods except cheese.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

I find groceries have gone up in price since 1910 and the farm housewife does more canning nowadays because fruit jars are more plentiful and the canning methods are more up to date.
21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods instead of home grown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

I always can my own produce and vegetables also. I seldom treat meat and fish.

Also make my own butter and sugar.

Very little canned goods except cheese.
